definition: A table used to record the values of variables as an algorithm runs to help find errors.
Data used to check that a program works correctly.
Test data that is typical and should be accepted by the program.
Test data at the extremes of acceptable ranges.
Automated checks to ensure data entered is reasonable and meets given rules.
Checking the identity of a user, for example with a username and password.
An error where code breaks the rules (grammar) of the programming language.
An error that occurs while the program is running, such as dividing by zero.
An error where the program runs but produces an incorrect result.
Removing unnecessary detail so that only the important information remains.
A step-by-step set of instructions for solving a problem.
Breaking a large problem down into smaller, more manageable parts.
Identifying similarities or trends within data or problems.
A tool that helps find and fix errors in code.
How easy it is to understand, modify and test code.
A debugging feature that allows code to be executed one line at a time.
Markers set in code where execution will pause during debugging so variables can be inspected.
Validation that checks that input has the correct number of characters.
Validation that checks that an input has actually been entered and is not blank.
Validation that checks that data falls within a specified range.
Validation that checks that data is of the correct data type, such as a number not text.
The base-2 number system that uses only the digits 0 and 1; used internally by computers.
The smallest unit of data; can store a 0 or 1.
A group of 4 bits.
A group of 8 bits; often used to store a single character.
The base-10 number system using digits 0–9.
1,024 bytes
1,024 Kibibtyes
1,024 Mebibytes
1,024 Gibibytes
The base-16 number system using digits 0–9 and A–F.
A binary number that can only represent positive values.
A binary number that can represent positive and negative values, often using two's complement.
A method for representing negative binary numbers by inverting bits and adding one.
An error that occurs when a calculation produces a value that is too large to store in the allocated bits.
Adding binary numbers using rules similar to denary addition with carrying.
Moving all bits in a binary number left or right, effectively multiplying or dividing by powers of two.
Shifts all bits left and fills vacated bits with 0; multiplies the value by 2.
Shifts all bits right and fills vacated bits with 0; divides the value by 2 (for unsigned numbers).
The leftmost bit in a binary number; represents the highest value place and may store the sign.
An image made up of a grid of pixels, each storing a colour value.
The smallest addressable element of an image.
The number of pixels in an image, usually width × height or pixels per inch.
The number of bits used to store the colour of each pixel.
Calculated by width × height × colour depth (in bits), often divided by 8 to get bytes.
A system that maps characters to binary values, such as ASCII or Unicode.
A character set that uses 7 or 8 bits to represent letters, digits and symbols.
A character set that can represent characters from many languages using more bits than ASCII.
Reducing the size of a file so that it takes up less storage space or transmits more quickly.
Compression that does not lose any data; the original file can be perfectly reconstructed.
Compression that removes some data to reduce file size, reducing quality.
Extra information stored with a file such as dimensions, colour depth or author.
A continuous signal that can take any value within a range.
A discrete signal that can only take certain values, such as 0 or 1.
The height of a wave; in sound, it relates to loudness.
Measuring the amplitude of an analogue signal at regular intervals.
The number of samples taken per second, measured in Hertz.
The time between samples; the inverse of sample rate.
The number of bits used for each sample; higher bit depth gives more precise sound.
Calculated as sample rate × bit depth × number of channels × duration (in seconds).
Part of the CPU that coordinates the activities of the CPU and decodes instructions.
Part of the CPU that performs arithmetic calculations and logical operations.
Very fast small memory locations inside the CPU for temporarily storing data and instructions.
Register that holds the address of the next instruction to be fetched.
Register that stores the result of calculations performed by the ALU.
Carries memory addresses from the CPU to main memory; usually one-way.
Carries data between the CPU, memory and other components.
Carries control signals used to coordinate the CPU and other components.
Number of cycles the CPU can carry out per second, measured in Hertz.
A single pulse of the CPU clock during which one or more operations may be carried out.
The number of bits that can be transferred simultaneously on a bus.
Volatile main memory used to store data and programs that are currently in use.
Non-volatile memory that stores data needed to start the computer, such as boot instructions.
Non-volatile storage such as hard drives, SSDs and optical discs used for long-term data storage.
The process by which the CPU fetches an instruction from memory, decodes it and executes it.
Storage that uses magnetised areas on a disk to represent data.
Storage that uses lasers to read and write data on optical media such as CDs or DVDs.
Storage that uses flash memory with no moving parts, such as SSDs and USB drives.
A computer system built into another device to perform one dedicated task.
A computer that can run many different programs and perform many tasks.
A small computer on a single chip containing a CPU, memory and input/output.
A device that converts electrical signals into physical movement.
A device that detects or measures a physical property and records, indicates or responds to it.
A programming language closer to natural language that is easier for humans to read and write.
A programming language close to machine code, giving more control over hardware.
Binary instructions that can be executed directly by the CPU.
Low-level language using mnemonics that correspond to machine code instructions.
A translator that converts assembly language into machine code.
Software that converts source code into machine code, such as a compiler or interpreter.
Translates the whole source code into machine code before execution.
Translates and executes a program line by line.
The original human-readable code written by a programmer.
Machine code produced by a translator that can be run by the CPU.
The part of an instruction that specifies the data or memory location to use.
The part of an instruction that specifies the operation to perform.
Short human-readable codes used in assembly language, such as ADD or MOV.
Software owned by an organisation; source code is not available to the public.
System software that performs maintenance tasks, such as backup or anti-virus.
Utility that detects and removes malware.
Software used to reduce the size of files.
Software or hardware that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic.
Software that automates copying data to another location for safekeeping.
Software that controls the hardware and provides a platform for applications.
System software that manages hardware, provides a user interface and runs applications.
The part of the OS that allocates and tracks use of main memory.
Using part of secondary storage as if it were RAM when physical RAM is full.
Organising files into folders, copying, moving, renaming and deleting files.
Using scheduling so the CPU appears to run many programs at once.
Deciding which process the CPU should execute next.
Controlling external devices such as printers and monitors using drivers.
Managing user accounts, logins and permissions.
Checking the identity of a user before allowing access.
The way in which a user interacts with a computer system, such as a GUI or CLI.
Software that allows the operating system to communicate with hardware devices.
Checking code written by others for errors and improvements.
Software that can cope with errors or unexpected input without crashing.
A low-level programming language using mnemonics that map directly to machine code instructions.
Each assembly instruction corresponds directly to one machine code instruction.
Easier for humans to read and write than binary; uses mnemonics instead of 0s and 1s.
Very fast execution and efficient memory use, giving direct control over hardware.
Harder to read, write and debug; often machine-specific.
Languages such as Python, Java, C++ and Visual Basic.
Easier to write, debug and maintain; portable across many systems.
Less control over hardware and generally slower than low-level languages.
Two or more computers or devices connected together to share data and resources.
A global network of interconnected computers and networks.
Local Area Network; covers a small geographical area such as a building or campus.
Wide Area Network; covers a large geographical area and connects multiple LANs.
A network that uses physical cables, such as Ethernet or fibre optic, to connect devices.
A network that uses radio waves (Wi-Fi) to connect devices without cables.
A device that connects devices on a LAN and forwards data to the correct device based on MAC address.
A device that forwards data packets between networks and connects a LAN to the internet.
The main high-capacity links that connect parts of a network.
A powerful computer that provides services or resources to other computers on a network.
The maximum amount of data that can be transmitted over a network in a given time, usually in bits per second.
The time delay between sending data and receiving a response.
A network layout where all devices are connected to a central switch or hub.
A network layout where all devices are connected to a single central cable.
A network layout where devices are interconnected, often with multiple paths between them.
Domain Name System; translates domain names into IP addresses.
A unique numerical address assigned to a device on a network using IP.
A unique numerical address assigned to a device on a network using IP.
A unique hardware address assigned to a network interface card.
A small chunk of data sent over a network, containing addressing and error-checking information.
Data used to detect errors in a packet during transmission.
Splitting data into packets which are sent independently and reassembled at the destination.
Hardware that connects a computer to a network.
A device that allows wireless devices to connect to a wired network.
A four-layer model describing how protocols work together to transmit data over networks.
Top layer of TCP/IP; chooses the correct protocol for an application.
Splits data into packets, adds port numbers and ensures reliable delivery.
Adds source and destination IP addresses and routes packets.
Handles hardware addressing (MAC) and physical transmission of data.
Hypertext Transfer Protocol; used for transferring web pages.
HTTP with encryption for secure communication over the internet.
Internet Message Access Protocol; retrieves email while keeping copies on the server.
Post Office Protocol version 3; retrieves email and usually deletes it from the server.
Simple Mail Transfer Protocol; sends email between mail servers.
Transmission Control Protocol; provides reliable, ordered delivery of packets.
Internet Protocol; responsible for addressing and routing packets between networks.
Monitors and filters network traffic to prevent unauthorised access.
Verifying the identity of a user, for example with a password or biometric.
Permissions that control what resources users can access on a network.
Converting data into a coded form so that only authorised users can read it.
Authorised simulated attacks on a network to find security weaknesses.
Protecting hardware using measures such as locks, alarms and secure rooms.
A set of rules governing how data is transmitted over a network.
The main high-speed routes that carry internet traffic across countries and continents.
Internet Service Provider; a company that provides users with internet access.
The impact of technology on the environment, such as energy use and electronic waste.
The duty to use technology in a safe, legal and ethical way.
Discarded electronic devices that can cause pollution if not disposed of properly.
Designing and using technology in a way that does not damage the environment or exhaust resources.
The study of what is morally right or wrong, beyond what is legal.
The gap between people who have access to digital technologies and those who do not.
Moral questions raised by the use of technology, such as privacy or job losses.
Controlling or suppressing what information people can access.
Concerns about how personal data is collected, stored, used and shared.
The right to express opinions without censorship, which can conflict with controlling harmful content.
Monitoring people's activities, often using technology such as CCTV or online tracking.
The effects of technology on traditions, behaviour and values in society.
Posting messages online to deliberately upset or provoke others.
False or misleading information presented as news.
UK law that controls how personal data is collected, stored and used.
UK law that makes unauthorised access to computer material a criminal offence.
Computer systems that perform tasks normally requiring human intelligence.
A type of AI where systems learn from data and improve over time without explicit programming.
AI-generated audio or video that convincingly mimics real people saying or doing things they did not do.
Using technology to perform tasks with little or no human input.
Laws and rules designed to ensure AI is used safely and fairly.
Unfair outcomes produced by AI systems because of biased training data or design.
Who is responsible for decisions made by AI systems.
Software whose source code is freely available to use, modify and distribute.
Commercial software owned by a company; users buy a licence to use it but cannot modify it.
A legal agreement that sets out how software can be used, copied and distributed.
Rules governing how software may be used, including open source (free to modify) and proprietary (restricted use).
Legal rights over creations of the mind such as software, music or designs.
UK law that protects original creative works from being copied or used without permission.Topic 5-Issues & Impact-cyber
column5: The financial, reputational and legal damage that can result from security breaches.

definition: UK law that controls how personal data is collected, stored and used.
UK law that makes unauthorised access to computer material a criminal offence.
UK law that protects original creative works from being copied or used without permission.
Rules governing how software may be used, including open source (free to modify) and proprietary (restricted use).
Stealing data for purposes such as identity theft or fraud.
Malicious software designed to damage or disrupt computer systems.
Malware that secretly collects information about a user or their computer.
Software that automatically displays or downloads unwanted advertising material.
Malware that encrypts files and demands payment to restore access.
Malware that attaches itself to programs or files and spreads when they are run.
Malware that can copy itself and spread independently over networks.
Malware disguised as legitimate software that, once installed, performs malicious actions.
Software designed to detect, block and remove malware.
A technique used by security software to detect new malware by its behaviour.
Patterns of code used by security software to identify known malware.
A person who gains unauthorised access to systems or data.
An update released to fix vulnerabilities or bugs in software.
Software that has not had the latest security updates applied and is vulnerable.
Hardware or software that controls incoming and outgoing network traffic based on security rules.
Using hacking skills legally to find and fix security weaknesses.
Authorised simulated attacks used to test the security of a system.
A hacker who uses skills for malicious or illegal purposes.
A hacker who uses skills to improve security, with permission.
Tricking people into giving away confidential information.
Fraudulent emails or messages that try to persuade people to reveal information.
Creating a false scenario to obtain sensitive information from someone.
Offering something attractive to trick a victim into compromising security, for example an infected USB drive.
Text in code that is ignored by the computer and used to explain the purpose of code.
A number with a decimal point.
Symbols such as +, -, *, /, //, %, ** used for mathematical calculations.
A self-contained block of code that performs a specific task.
Data sent into a program to be processed.
A single letter, digit or symbol.
==, !=, <, >, <=, >= used to compare values.
A subprogram that returns a value.
Processed data sent out from a program to the user or another system.
A sequence of characters treated as text.
AND, OR, NOT used in logical expressions.
A subprogram that performs a task but does not return a value.
A named memory location that stores a value that can change while the program runs.
A data type with only two possible values: True or False.
A variable that increases or decreases by a fixed amount each time through a loop.
A variable that can be accessed from any part of the program.
A named value that does not change while the program runs.
Using conditions (such as IF) so that different code runs depending on whether a condition is true or false.
A Boolean variable used to signal that a condition or event has occurred.
A variable that can only be accessed inside the subprogram in which it is declared.
The name given to a variable, constant, subprogram or other program element.
A set of instructions that are executed one after another in order.
A fixed-size collection of elements of the same data type stored under one identifier.
Opening, reading, writing and closing files in a program.
Giving a variable or constant a value using the assignment operator.
Executing a block of code a fixed number of times (for example, a counted loop).
A data structure that groups related items of different data types under one name.
Operations performed on strings, such as concatenation, slicing or changing case.
A whole number with no decimal part.
Repeating a block of code, often using a loop structure.
A list or array of lists, often visualised as rows and columns like a table.
Data passed into a subprogram, written in brackets when the subprogram is called.
A fixed-size data structure that stores items of the same type under one identifier.
Giving a variable or constant a value.
A section of code, usually grouped by indentation or braces.
A data type with only two values: true or false.
To execute the code inside a subprogram.
Converting a value from one data type to another.
A comparison that evaluates to true or false and controls selection or repetition.
A value that does not change while the program is running.
The kind of data stored, such as integer, real, Boolean or string.
A way of organising and storing data, such as arrays, lists or records.
Breaking a large problem into smaller subproblems.
Reducing the value of a variable, often by 1.
To introduce a new variable or data structure, often specifying its type.
A collection of data stored on secondary storage.
A Boolean variable used to indicate that a certain condition has been met.
A number with a decimal point; also known as a real number.
A subprogram that performs a task and returns a value.
The name of a variable, constant, subprogram or data structure.
Increasing the value of a variable, often by 1.
Giving a variable or data structure its first value.
A whole number with no fractional part.
Repeating a block of code, usually with a loop.
A collection of pre-written functions and procedures that can be imported into programs.
A variable-size data structure that can store multiple values, often of mixed types.
An error where the program runs but does not behave as intended.
A structure that repeats a block of code while a condition is met or for a fixed number of times.
An operator that gives the remainder after integer division.
Putting one programming construct, such as a loop or selection, inside another.
A symbol that tells the program to perform a specific operation, such as + or AND.
A variable in the definition of a subprogram that receives an argument when called.
Brackets used to group expressions or to enclose arguments.
A subprogram that performs a task but does not return a value.
A loop that continues until a condition is met.
A construct that chooses which code to execute based on conditions.
Executing instructions one after another in a specific order.
Data type used to store text as a sequence of characters.
An error where code breaks the rules of the programming language and will not run.
A number that can have a fractional part; same as a float.
The value a function sends back to the code that called it.
To start executing a program.
A smaller, reusable section of code, such as a function or procedure.
A named storage location in memory that can hold a value that may change while the program runs.
A simple search method that checks each item in a list one by one until the target value is found or the end is reached.
Linear search is used when the data is unsorted or small.
It is slow on large lists because every item may need to be checked.
A search method that repeatedly halves a sorted list to find the target value.
Binary search can only be used on lists that are already sorted.
It is more efficient than linear search because it reduces the search space quickly.
A simple sorting algorithm that repeatedly compares and swaps adjacent items until the list is sorted.
Bubble sort is slow on large lists because it may require many passes through the data.
A sorting algorithm that splits the list into smaller lists, sorts them, and then merges them back together.
Uses a divide-and-conquer approach to efficiently sort data.
It is faster than bubble sort for large lists but uses more memory.
A measure of how quickly an algorithm runs and how much memory it uses.
A way to compare how the running time of algorithms increases as the input size grows.
Some algorithms use more memory because they store extra copies of data.
An algorithm that completes its task quickly and uses minimal memory.
Outputs 1 only when all inputs are 1.
Outputs 1 when at least one input is 1.
Outputs the opposite value of the input (1 becomes 0, and 0 becomes 1).
A table showing all possible input combinations and the resulting output for a logic gate.
